books.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:1
verses.text: On the Flesh of Christ: This was written by our author in confutation of certain heretics who denied the reality of Christ's flesh, or at least its identity with human flesh—fearing that, if they admitted the reality of Christ's flesh, they must also admit his resurrection in the flesh; and, consequently, the resurrection of the human body after death.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:2
verses.text: The General Purport of This Work.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:3
verses.text: The Heretics, Marcion, Apelles, and Valentinus, Wishing to Impugn the Doctrine of the Resurrection, Deprive Christ of All Capacity for Such a Change by Denying His Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:4
verses.text: They who are so anxious to shake that belief in the resurrection which was firmly settled before the appearance of our modern Sadducees, as even to deny that the expectation thereof has any relation whatever to the flesh, have great cause for besetting the flesh of Christ also with doubtful questions, as if it either had no existence at all, or possessed a nature altogether different from human flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:5
verses.text: For they cannot but be apprehensive that, if it be once determined that Christ's flesh was human, a presumption would immediately arise in opposition to them, that that flesh must by all means rise again, which has already risen in Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:6
verses.text: Therefore we shall have to guard our belief in the resurrection from the same armoury, whence they get their weapons of destruction.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:7
verses.text: Let us examine our Lord's bodily substance, for about His spiritual nature all are agreed.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:8
verses.text: It is His flesh that is in question.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:9
verses.text: Its verity and quality are the points in dispute.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:10
verses.text: Did it ever exist? whence was it derived? and of what kind was it? If we succeed in demonstrating it, we shall lay down a law for our own resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:11
verses.text: Marcion, in order that he might deny the flesh of Christ, denied also His nativity, or else he denied His flesh in order that he might deny His nativity; because, of course, he was afraid that His nativity and His flesh bore mutual testimony to each other's reality, since there is no nativity without flesh, and no flesh without nativity.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:12
verses.text: As if indeed, under the prompting of that licence which is ever the same in all heresy, he too might not very well have either denied the nativity, although admitting the flesh,—like Apelles, who was first a disciple of his, and afterwards an apostate,—or, while admitting both the flesh and the nativity, have interpreted them in a different sense, as did Valentinus, who resembled Apelles both in his discipleship and desertion of Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:13
verses.text: At all events, he who represented the flesh of Christ to be imaginary was equally able to pass off His nativity as a phantom; so that the virgin's conception, and pregnancy, and child-bearing, and then the whole course of her infant too, would have to be regarded as putative.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 1:14
verses.text: These facts pertaining to the nativity of Christ would escape the notice of the same eyes and the same senses as failed to grasp the full idea of His flesh.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:1
verses.text: Marcion, Who Would Blot Out the Record of Christ's Nativity, is Rebuked for So Startling a Heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:2
verses.text: Clearly enough is the nativity announced by Gabriel.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:3
verses.text: But what has he to do with the Creator's angel? The conception in the virgin's womb is also set plainly before us.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:4
verses.text: But what concern has he with the Creator's prophet, Isaiah? He will not brook delay, since suddenly (without any prophetic announcement) did he bring down Christ from heaven.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:5
verses.text: "Away," says he, "with that eternal plaguey taxing of Caesar, and the scanty inn, and the squalid swaddling-clothes, and the hard stable.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:6
verses.text: We do not care a jot for that multitude of the heavenly host which praised their Lord at night.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:7
verses.text: Let the shepherds take better care of their flock, and let the wise men spare their legs so long a journey; let them keep their gold to themselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:8
verses.text: Let Herod, too, mend his manners, so that Jeremy may not glory over him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:9
verses.text: Spare also the babe from circumcision, that he may escape the pain thereof; nor let him be brought into the temple, lest he burden his parents with the expense of the offering; nor let him be handed to Simeon, lest the old man be saddened at the point of death.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:10
verses.text: Let that old woman also hold her tongue, lest she should bewitch the child".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:11
verses.text: After such a fashion as this, I suppose you have had, O Marcion, the hardihood of blotting out the original records (of the history) of Christ, that His flesh may lose the proofs of its reality.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:12
verses.text: But, prithee, on what grounds (do you do this)? Show me your authority.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:13
verses.text: If you are a prophet, foretell us a thing; if you are an apostle, open your message in public; if a follower of apostles, side with apostles in thought; if you are only a (private) Christian, believe what has been handed down to us: if, however, you are nothing of all this, then (as I have the best reason to say) cease to live.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:14
verses.text: For indeed you are already dead, since you are no Christian, because you do not believe that which by being believed makes men Christian,—nay, you are the more dead, the more you are not a Christian; having fallen away, after you had been one, by rejecting what you formerly believed, even as you yourself acknowledge in a certain letter of yours, and as your followers do not deny, whilst our (brethren) can prove it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:15
verses.text: Rejecting, therefore, what you once believed, you have completed the act of rejection, by now no longer believing:  the fact, however, of your having ceased to believe has not made your rejection of the faith right and proper; nay, rather, by your act of rejection you prove that what you believed previous to the said act was of a different character.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:16
verses.text: What you believed to be of a different character, had been handed down just as you believed it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:17
verses.text: Now that which had been handed down was true, inasmuch as it had been transmitted by those whose duty it was to hand it down.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:18
verses.text: Therefore, when rejecting that which had been handed down, you rejected that which was true.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:19
verses.text: You had no authority for what you did.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:20
verses.text: However, we have already in another treatise availed ourselves more fully of these prescriptive rules against all heresies.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 2:21
verses.text: Our repetition of them hereafter that large (treatise) is superfluous, when we ask the reason why you have formed the opinion that Christ was not born.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:1
verses.text: Christ's Nativity Both Possible and Becoming.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:2
verses.text: The Heretical Opinion of Christ's Apparent Flesh Deceptive and Dishonourable to God, Even on Marcion's Principles.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:3
verses.text: Since you think that this lay within the competency of your own arbitrary choice, you must needs have supposed that being born was either impossible for God, or unbecoming to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:4
verses.text: With God, however, nothing is impossible but what He does not will.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:5
verses.text: Let us consider, then, whether He willed to be born (for if He had the will, He also had the power, and was born).

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:6
verses.text: I put the argument very briefly.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:7
verses.text: If God had willed not to be born, it matters not why, He would not have presented Himself in the likeness of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:8
verses.text: Now who, when he sees a man, would deny that he had been born?  What God therefore willed not to be, He would in no wise have willed the seeming to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:9
verses.text: When a thing is distasteful, the very notion of it is scouted; because it makes no difference whether a thing exist or do not exist, if, when it does not exist, it is yet assumed to exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:10
verses.text: It is of course of the greatest importance that there should be nothing false (or pretended) attributed to that which really does not exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:11
verses.text: But, say you, His own consciousness (of the truth of His nature) was enough for Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:12
verses.text: If any supposed that He had been born, because they saw Him as a man, that was their concern.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:13
verses.text: Yet with how much more dignity and consistency would He have sustained the human character on the supposition that He was truly born; for if He were not born, He could not have undertaken the said character without injury to that consciousness of His which you on your side attribute to His confidence of being able to sustain, although not born, the character of having been born even against!  His own consciousness! Why, I want to know, was it of so much importance, that Christ should, when perfectly aware what He really was, exhibit Himself as being that which He was not? You cannot express any apprehension that, if He had been born and truly clothed Himself with man's nature, He would have ceased to be God, losing what He was, while becoming what He was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:14
verses.text: For God is in no danger of losing His own state and condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:15
verses.text: But, say you, I deny that God was truly changed to man in such wise as to be born and endued with a body of flesh, on this ground, that a being who is without end is also of necessity incapable of change.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:16
verses.text: For being changed into something else puts an end to the former state.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:17
verses.text: Change, therefore, is not possible to a Being who cannot come to an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:18
verses.text: Without doubt, the nature of things which are subject to change is regulated by this law, that they have no permanence in the state which is undergoing change in them, and that they come to an end from thus wanting permanence, whilst they lose that in the process of change which they previously were.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:19
verses.text: But nothing is equal with God; His nature is different from the condition of all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:20
verses.text: If, then, the things which differ from God, and from which God differs, lose what existence they had whilst they are undergoing change, wherein will consist the difference of the Divine Being from all other things except in His possessing the contrary faculty of theirs,—in other words, that God can be changed into all conditions, and yet continue just as He is? On any other supposition, He would be on the same level with those things which, when changed, lose the existence they had before; whose equal, of course, He is not in any other respect, as He certainly is not in the changeful issues of their nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:21
verses.text: You have sometimes read and believed that the Creator's angels have been changed into human form, and have even borne about so veritable a body, that Abraham even washed their feet, and Lot was rescued from the Sodomites by their hands; an angel, moreover, wrestled with a man so strenuously with his body, that the latter desired to be let loose, so tightly was he held.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:22
verses.text: Has it, then, been permitted to angels, which are inferior to God, after they have been changed into human bodily form, nevertheless to remain angels? and will you deprive God, their superior, of this faculty, as if Christ could not continue to be God, after His real assumption of the nature of man? Or else, did those angels appear as phantoms of flesh? You will not, however, have the courage to say this; for if it be so held in your belief, that the Creator's angels are in the same condition as Christ, then Christ will belong to the same God as those angels do, who are like Christ in their condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:23
verses.text: If you had not purposely rejected in some instances, and corrupted in others, the Scriptures which are opposed to your opinion, you would have been confuted in this matter by the Gospel of John, when it declares that the Spirit descended in the body of a dove, and sat upon the Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:24
verses.text: When the said Spirit was in this condition, He was as truly a dove as He was also a spirit; nor did He destroy His own proper substance by the assumption of an extraneous substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:25
verses.text: But you ask what becomes of the dove's body, after the return of the Spirit back to heaven, and similarly in the case of the angels.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:26
verses.text: Their withdrawal was effected in the same manner as their appearance had been.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:27
verses.text: If you had seen how their production out of nothing had been effected, you would have known also the process of their return to nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:28
verses.text: If the initial step was out of sight, so was also the final one.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:29
verses.text: Still there was solidity in their bodily substance, whatever may have been the force by which the body became visible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 3:30
verses.text: What is written cannot but have been.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:1
verses.text: God's Honour in the Incarnation of His Son Vindicated.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:2
verses.text: Marcion's Disparagement of Human Flesh Inconsistent as Well as Impious.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:3
verses.text: Christ Has Cleansed the Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:4
verses.text: The Foolishness of God is Most Wise.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:5
verses.text: Since, therefore, you do not reject the assumption of a body as impossible or as hazardous to the character of God, it remains for you to repudiate and censure it as unworthy of Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:6
verses.text: Come now, beginning from the nativity itself, declaim against the uncleanness of the generative elements within the womb, the filthy concretion of fluid and blood, of the growth of the flesh for nine months long out of that very mire.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:7
verses.text: Describe the womb as it enlarges from day to day, heavy, troublesome, restless even in sleep, changeful in its feelings of dislike and desire.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:8
verses.text: Inveigh now likewise against the shame itself of a woman in travail which, however, ought rather to be honoured in consideration of that peril, or to be held sacred in respect of (the mystery of) nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:9
verses.text: Of course you are horrified also at the infant, which is shed into life with the embarrassments which accompany it from the womb; you likewise, of course, loathe it even after it is washed, when it is dressed out in its swaddling-clothes, graced with repeated anointing, smiled on with nurse's fawns.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:10
verses.text: This reverend course of nature, you, O Marcion, (are pleased to) spit upon; and yet, in what way were you born? You detest a human being at his birth; then after what fashion do you love anybody? Yourself, of course, you had no love of, when you departed from the Church and the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:11
verses.text: But never mind, if you are not on good terms with yourself, or even if you were born in a way different from other people.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:12
verses.text: Christ, at any rate, has loved even that man who was condensed in his mother's womb amidst all its uncleannesses, even that man who was brought into life out of the said womb, even that man who was nursed amidst the nurse's simpers.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:13
verses.text: For his sake He came down (from heaven), for his sake He preached, for his sake "He humbled Himself even unto death—the death of the cross".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:14
verses.text: He loved, of course, the being whom He redeemed at so great a cost.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:15
verses.text: If Christ is the Creator's Son, it was with justice that He loved His own (creature); if He comes from another god, His love was excessive, since He redeemed a being who belonged to another.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:16
verses.text: Well, then, loving man He loved his nativity also, and his flesh as well.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:17
verses.text: Nothing can be loved apart from that through which whatever exists has its existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:18
verses.text: Either take away nativity, and then show us your man; or else withdraw the flesh, and then present to our view the being whom God has redeemed—since it is these very conditions which constitute the man whom God has redeemed.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:19
verses.text: And are you for turning these conditions into occasions of blushing to the very creature whom He has redeemed, (censuring them), too, as unworthy of Him who certainly would not have redeemed them had He not loved them?  Our birth He reforms from death by a second birth from heaven; our flesh He restores from every harassing malady; when leprous, He cleanses it of the stain; when blind, He rekindles its light; when palsied, He renews its strength; when possessed with devils, He exorcises it; when dead, He reanimates it,—then shall we blush to own it? If, to be sure, He had chosen to be born of a mere animal, and were to preach the kingdom of heaven invested with the body of a beast either wild or tame, your censure (I imagine) would have instantly met Him with this demurrer: "This is disgraceful for God, and this is unworthy of the Son of God, and simply foolish".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:20
verses.text: For no other reason than because one thus judges.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:21
verses.text: It is of course foolish, if we are to judge God by our own conceptions.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:22
verses.text: But, Marcion, consider well this Scripture, if indeed you have not erased it: "God hath chosen the foolish things of the world, to confound the wise".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:23
verses.text: Now what are those foolish things? Are they the conversion of men to the worship of the true God, the rejection of error, the whole training in righteousness, chastity, mercy, patience, and innocence?  These things certainly are not "foolish".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:24
verses.text: Inquire again, then, of what things he spoke, and when you imagine that you have discovered what they are will you find anything to be so "foolish" as believing in a God that has been born, and that of a virgin, and of a fleshly nature too, who wallowed in all the before-mentioned humiliations of nature?  But some one may say, "These are not the foolish things; they must be other things which God has chosen to confound the wisdom of the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 4:25
verses.text: And yet, according to the world's wisdom, it is more easy to believe that Jupiter became a bull or a swan, if we listen to Marcion, than that Christ really became a man.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:1
verses.text: Christ Truly Lived and Died in Human Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:2
verses.text: Incidents of His Human Life on Earth, and Refutation of Marcion's Docetic Parody of the Same.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:3
verses.text: There are, to be sure, other things also quite as foolish (as the birth of Christ), which have reference to the humiliations and sufferings of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:4
verses.text: Or else, let them call a crucified God "wisdom".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:5
verses.text: But Marcion will apply the knife to this doctrine also, and even with greater reason.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:6
verses.text: For which is more unworthy of God, which is more likely to raise a blush of shame, that God should be born, or that He should die? that He should bear the flesh, or the cross? be circumcised, or be crucified? be cradled, or be coffined? be laid in a manger, or in a tomb? Talk of "wisdom!" You will show more of that if you refuse to believe this also.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:7
verses.text: But, after all, you will not be "wise" unless you become a "fool" to the world, by believing "the foolish things of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:8
verses.text: Have you, then, cut away all sufferings from Christ, on the ground that, as a mere phantom, He was incapable of experiencing them? We have said above that He might possibly have undergone the unreal mockeries of an imaginary birth and infancy.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:9
verses.text: But answer me at once, you that murder truth:  Was not God really crucified?  And, having been really crucified, did He not really die? And, having indeed really died, did He not really rise again? Falsely did Paul "determine to know nothing amongst us but Jesus and Him crucified;" falsely has he impressed upon us that He was buried; falsely inculcated that He rose again.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:10
verses.text: False, therefore, is our faith also.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:11
verses.text: And all that we hope for from Christ will be a phantom.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:12
verses.text: O thou most infamous of men, who acquittest of all guilt the murderers of God! For nothing did Christ suffer from them, if He really suffered nothing at all.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:13
verses.text: Spare the whole world's one only hope, thou who art destroying the indispensable dishonour of our faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:14
verses.text: Whatsoever is unworthy of God, is of gain to me.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:15
verses.text: I am safe, if I am not ashamed of my Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:16
verses.text: "Whosoever," says He, "shall be ashamed of me, of him will I also be ashamed".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:17
verses.text: Other matters for shame find I none which can prove me to be shameless in a good sense, and foolish in a happy one, by my own contempt of shame.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:18
verses.text: The Son of God was crucified; I am not ashamed because men must needs be ashamed of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:19
verses.text: And the Son of God died; it is by all means to be believed, because it is absurd.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:20
verses.text: And He was buried, and rose again; the fact is certain, because it is impossible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:21
verses.text: But how will all this be true in Him, if He was not Himself true—if He really had not in Himself that which might be crucified, might die, might be buried, and might rise again? I mean this flesh suffused with blood, built up with bones, interwoven with nerves, entwined with veins, a flesh which knew how to be born, and how to die, human without doubt, as born of a human being.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:22
verses.text: It will therefore be mortal in Christ, because Christ is man and the Son of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:23
verses.text: Else why is Christ man and the Son of man, if he has nothing of man, and nothing from man? Unless it be either that man is anything else than flesh, or man's flesh comes from any other source than man, or Mary is anything else than a human being, or Marcion's man is as Marcion's god.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:24
verses.text: Otherwise Christ could not be described as being man without flesh, nor the Son of man without any human parent; just as He is not God without the Spirit of God, nor the Son of God without having God for His father.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:25
verses.text: Thus the nature of the two substances displayed Him as man and God,—in one respect born, in the other unborn; in one respect fleshly, in the other spiritual; in one sense weak, in the other exceeding strong; in one sense dying, in the other living.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:26
verses.text: This property of the two states—the divine and the human—is distinctly asserted with equal truth of both natures alike, with the same belief both in respect of the Spirit and of the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:27
verses.text: The powers of the Spirit, proved Him to be God, His sufferings attested the flesh of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:28
verses.text: If His powers were not without the Spirit in like manner, were not His sufferings without the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:29
verses.text: If His flesh with its sufferings was fictitious, for the same reason was the Spirit false with all its powers.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:30
verses.text: Wherefore halve Christ with a lie? He was wholly the truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:31
verses.text: Believe me, He chose rather to be born, than in any part to pretend—and that indeed to His own detriment—that He was bearing about a flesh hardened without bones, solid without muscles, bloody without blood, clothed without the tunic of skin, hungry without appetite, eating without teeth, speaking without a tongue, so that His word was a phantom to the ears through an imaginary voice.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:32
verses.text: A phantom, too, it was of course after the resurrection, when, showing His hands and His feet for the disciples to examine, He said, "Behold and see that it is I myself, for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have;" without doubt, hands, and feet, and bones are not what a spirit possesses, but only the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 5:33
verses.text: How do you interpret this statement, Marcion, you who tell us that Jesus comes only from the most excellent God, who is both simple and good? See how He rather cheats, and deceives, and juggles the eyes of all, and the senses of all, as well as their access to and contact with Him! You ought rather to have brought Christ down, not from heaven, but from some troop of mountebanks, not as God besides man, but simply as a man, a magician; not as the High Priest of our salvation, but as the conjurer in a show; not as the raiser of the dead, but as the misleader of the living,—except that, if He were a magician, He must have had a nativity!.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:1
verses.text: The Doctrine of Apelles Refuted, that Christ's Body Was of Sidereal Substance, Not Born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:2
verses.text: Nativity and Mortality are Correlative Circumstances, and in Christ's Case His Death Proves His Birth.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:3
verses.text: But certain disciples of the heretic of Pontus, compelled to be wiser than their teacher, concede to Christ real flesh, without effect, however, on their denial of His nativity.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:4
verses.text: He might have had, they say, a flesh which was not at all born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:5
verses.text: So we have found our way "out of a frying-pan," as the proverb runs, "into the fire,"—from Marcion to Apelles.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:6
verses.text: This man having first fallen from the principles of Marcion into (intercourse with) a woman, in the flesh, and afterwards shipwrecked himself, in the spirit, on the virgin Philumene, proceeded from that time to preach that the body of Christ was of solid flesh, but without having been born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:7
verses.text: To this angel, indeed, of Philumene, the apostle will reply in tones like those in which he even then predicted him, saying, "Although an angel from heaven preach any other gospel unto you than that which we have preached unto you, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:8
verses.text: To the arguments, however, which have been indicated just above, we have now to show our resistance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:9
verses.text: They allow that Christ really had a body.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:10
verses.text: Whence was the material of it, if not from the same sort of thing as that in which He appeared? Whence came His body, if His body were not flesh?  Whence came His flesh, if it were not born? Inasmuch as that which is born must undergo this nativity in order to become flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:11
verses.text: He borrowed, they say, His flesh from the stars, and from the substances of the higher world.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:12
verses.text: And they assert it for a certain principle, that a body without nativity is nothing to be astonished at, because it has been submitted to angels to appear even amongst ourselves in the flesh without the intervention of the womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:13
verses.text: We admit, of course, that such facts have been related.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:14
verses.text: But then, how comes it to pass that a faith which holds to a different rule borrows materials for its own arguments from the faith which it impugns? What has it to do with Moses, who has rejected the God of Moses? Since the God is a different one, everything belonging to him must be different also.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:15
verses.text: But let the heretics always use the Scriptures of that God whose world they also enjoy.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:16
verses.text: The fact will certainly recoil on them as a witness to judge them, that they maintain their own blasphemies from examples derived from Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:17
verses.text: But it is an easy task for the truth to prevail without raising any such demurrer against them.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:18
verses.text: When, therefore, they set forth the flesh of Christ after the pattern of the angels, declaring it to be not born, and yet flesh for all that, I should wish them to compare the causes, both in Christ's case and that of the angels, wherefore they came in the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:19
verses.text: Never did any angel descend for the purpose of being crucified, of tasting death, and of rising again from the dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:20
verses.text: Now, since there never was such a reason for angels becoming embodied, you have the cause why they assumed flesh without undergoing birth.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:21
verses.text: They had not come to die, therefore they also (came not) to be born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:22
verses.text: Christ, however, having been sent to die, had necessarily to be also born, that He might be capable of death; for nothing is in the habit of dying but that which is born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:23
verses.text: Between nativity and mortality there is a mutual contrast.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:24
verses.text: The law which makes us die is the cause of our being born.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:25
verses.text: Now, since Christ died owing to the condition which undergoes death, but that undergoes death which is also born, the consequence was—nay, it was an antecedent necessity—that He must have been born also, by reason of the condition which undergoes birth; because He had to die in obedience to that very condition which, because it begins with birth, ends in death.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:26
verses.text: It was not fitting for Him not to be born under the pretence that it was fitting for Him to die.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:27
verses.text: But the Lord Himself at that very time appeared to Abraham amongst those angels without being born, and yet in the flesh without doubt, in virtue of the before-mentioned diversity of cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:28
verses.text: You, however, cannot admit this, since you do not receive that Christ, who was even then rehearsing how to converse with, and liberate, and judge the human race, in the habit of a flesh which as yet was not born, because it did not yet mean to die until both its nativity and mortality were previously (by prophecy) announced.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:29
verses.text: Let them, then, prove to us that those angels derived their flesh from the stars.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:30
verses.text: If they do not prove it because it is not written, neither will the flesh of Christ get its origin therefrom, for which they borrowed the precedent of the angels.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:31
verses.text: It is plain that the angels bore a flesh which was not naturally their own; their nature being of a spiritual substance, although in some sense peculiar to themselves, corporeal; and yet they could be transfigured into human shape, and for the time be able to appear and have intercourse with men.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:32
verses.text: Since, therefore, it has not been told us whence they obtained their flesh, it remains for us not to doubt in our minds that a property of angelic power is this, to assume to themselves bodily shape out of no material substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:33
verses.text: How much more, you say, is it (within their competence to take a body) out of some material substance? That is true enough.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:34
verses.text: But there is no evidence of this, because Scripture says nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:35
verses.text: Then, again, how should they who are able to form themselves into that which by nature they are not, be unable to do this out of no material substance? If they become that which they are not, why cannot they so become out of that which is not? But that which has not existence when it comes into existence, is made out of nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:36
verses.text: This is why it is unnecessary either to inquire or to demonstrate what has subsequently become of their bodies.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:37
verses.text: What came out of nothing, came to nothing.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:38
verses.text: They, who were able to convert themselves into flesh have it in their power to convert nothing itself into flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:39
verses.text: It is a greater thing to change a nature than to make matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:40
verses.text: But even if it were necessary to suppose that angels derived their flesh from some material substance, it is surely more credible that it was from some earthly matter than from any kind of celestial substances, since it was composed of so palpably terrene a quality that it fed on earthly ailments.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:41
verses.text: Suppose that even now a celestial flesh had fed on earthly aliments, although it was not itself earthly, in the same way that earthly flesh actually fed on celestial aliments, although it had nothing of the celestial nature (for we read of manna having been food for the people: "Man," says the Psalmist, "did eat angels' bread,") yet this does not once infringe the separate condition of the Lord's flesh, because of His different destination.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:42
verses.text: For One who was to be truly a man, even unto death, it was necessary that He should be clothed with that flesh to which death belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 6:43
verses.text: Now that flesh to which death belongs is preceded by birth.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:1
verses.text: Explanation of the Lord's Question About His Mother and His Brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:2
verses.text: Answer to the Cavils of Apelles and Marcion, Who Support Their Denial of Christ's Nativity by It.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:3
verses.text: But whenever a dispute arises about the nativity, all who reject it as creating a presumption in favour of the reality of Christ's flesh, wilfully deny that God Himself was born, on the ground that He asked, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren?" Let, therefore, Apelles hear what was our answer to Marcion in that little work, in which we challenged his own (favourite) gospel to the proof, even that the material circumstances of that remark (of the Lord's) should be considered.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:4
verses.text: First of all, nobody would have told Him that His mother and brethren were standing outside, if he were not certain both that He had a mother and brethren, and that they were the very persons whom he was then announcing,—who had either been known to him before, or were then and there discovered by him; although heretics have removed this passage from the gospel, because those who were admiring His doctrine said that His supposed father, Joseph the carpenter, and His mother Mary, and His brethren, and His sisters, were very well known to them.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:5
verses.text: But it was with the view of tempting Him, that they had mentioned to Him a mother and brethren which He did not possess.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:6
verses.text: The Scripture says nothing of this, although it is not in other instances silent when anything was done against Him by way of temptation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:7
verses.text: "Behold," it says, "a certain lawyer stood up, and tempted Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:8
verses.text: And in another passage: "The Pharisees also came unto Him, tempting Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:9
verses.text: Who was to prevent its being in this place also indicated that this was done with the view of tempting Him? I do not admit what you advance of your own apart from Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:10
verses.text: Then there ought to be suggested some occasion for the temptation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:11
verses.text: What could they have thought to be in Him which required temptation?  The question, to be sure, whether He had been born or not? For if this point were denied in His answer, it might come out on the announcement of a temptation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:12
verses.text: And yet no temptation, when aiming at the discovery of the point which prompts the temptation by its doubtfulness, falls upon one so abruptly, as not to be preceded by the question which compels the temptation whilst raising the doubt.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:13
verses.text: Now, since the nativity of Christ had never come into question, how can you contend that they meant by their temptation to inquire about a point on which they had never raised a doubt?  Besides, if He had to be tempted about His birth, this of course was not the proper way of doing it,—by announcing those persons who, even on the supposition of His birth, might possibly not have been in existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:14
verses.text: We have all been born, and yet all of us have not either brothers or mother.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:15
verses.text: He might with more probability have had even a father than a mother, and uncles more likely than brothers.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:16
verses.text: Thus is the temptation about His birth unsuitable, for it might have been contrived without any mention of either His mother or His brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:17
verses.text: It is clearly more credible that, being certain that He had both a mother and brothers, they tested His divinity rather than His nativity, whether, when within, He knew what was without; being tried by the untrue announcement of the presence of persons who were not present.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:18
verses.text: But the artifice of a temptation might have been thwarted thus:  it might have happened that He knew that those whom they were announcing to be "standing without," were in fact absent by the stress either of sickness, or of business, or a journey which He was at the time aware of.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:19
verses.text: No one tempts (another) in a way in which he knows that he may have himself to bear the shame of the temptation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:20
verses.text: There being, then, no suitable occasion for a temptation, the announcement that His mother and His brethren had actually turned up recovers its naturalness.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:21
verses.text: But there is some ground for thinking that Christ's answer denies His mother and brethren for the present, as even Apelles might learn.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:22
verses.text: "The Lord's brethren had not yet believed in Him".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:23
verses.text: So is it contained in the Gospel which was published before Marcion's time; whilst there is at the same time a want of evidence of His mother's adherence to Him, although the Marthas and the other Marys were in constant attendance on Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:24
verses.text: In this very passage indeed, their unbelief is evident.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:25
verses.text: Jesus was teaching the way of life, preaching the kingdom of God and actively engaged in healing infirmities of body and soul; but all the while, whilst strangers were intent on Him, His very nearest relatives were absent.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:26
verses.text: By and by they turn up, and keep outside; but they do not go in, because, forsooth, they set small store on that which was doing within; nor do they even wait, as if they had something which they could contribute more necessary than that which He was so earnestly doing; but they prefer to interrupt Him, and wish to call Him away from His great work.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:27
verses.text: Now, I ask you, Apelles, or will you Marcion, please (to tell me), if you happened to be at a stage play, or had laid a wager on a foot race or a chariot race, and were called away by such a message, would you not have exclaimed, "What are mother and brothers to me?" And did not Christ, whilst preaching and manifesting God, fulfilling the law and the prophets, and scattering the darkness of the long preceding age, justly employ this same form of words, in order to strike the unbelief of those who stood outside, or to shake off the importunity of those who would call Him away from His work? If, however, He had meant to deny His own nativity, He would have found place, time, and means for expressing Himself very differently, and not in words which might be uttered by one who had both a mother and brothers.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:28
verses.text: When denying one's parents in indignation, one does not deny their existence, but censures their faults.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:29
verses.text: Besides, He gave others the preference; and since He shows their title to this favour—even because they listened to the word (of God)—He points out in what sense He denied His mother and His brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:30
verses.text: For in whatever sense He adopted as His own those who adhered to Him, in that did He deny as His those who kept aloof from Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:31
verses.text: Christ also is wont to do to the utmost that which He enjoins on others.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:32
verses.text: How strange, then, would it certainly have been, if, while he was teaching others not to esteem mother, or father, or brothers, as highly as the word of God, He were Himself to leave the word of God as soon as His mother and brethren were announced to Him! He denied His parents, then, in the sense in which He has taught us to deny ours—for God's work.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:33
verses.text: But there is also another view of the case: in the abjured mother there is a figure of the synagogue, as well as of the Jews in the unbelieving brethren.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:34
verses.text: In their person Israel remained outside, whilst the new disciples who kept close to Christ within, hearing and believing, represented the Church, which He called mother in a preferable sense and a worthier brotherhood, with the repudiation of the carnal relationship.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 7:35
verses.text: It was in just the same sense, indeed, that He also replied to that exclamation (of a certain woman), not denying His mother's "womb and paps," but designating those as more "blessed who hear the word of God".

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:1
verses.text: Apelles and His Followers, Displeased with Our Earthly Bodies, Attributed to Christ a Body of a Purer Sort.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:2
verses.text: How Christ Was Heavenly Even in His Earthly Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:3
verses.text: These passages alone, in which Apelles and Marcion seem to place their chief reliance when interpreted according to the truth of the entire uncorrupted gospel, ought to have been sufficient for proving the human flesh of Christ by a defence of His birth.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:4
verses.text: But since Apelles' precious set lay a very great stress on the shameful condition of the flesh, which they will have to have been furnished with souls tampered with by the fiery author of evil, and so unworthy of Christ; and because they on that account suppose that a sidereal substance is suitable for Him, I am bound to refute them on their own ground.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:5
verses.text: They mention a certain angel of great renown as having created this world of ours, and as having, after the creation, repented of his work.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:6
verses.text: This indeed we have treated of in a passage by itself; for we have written a little work in opposition to them, on the question whether one who had the spirit, and will, and power of Christ for such operations, could have done anything which required repentance, since they describe the said angel by the figure of "the lost sheep".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:7
verses.text: The world, then, must be a wrong thing, according to the evidence of its Creator's repentance; for all repentance is the admission of fault, nor has it indeed any existence except through fault.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:8
verses.text: Now, if the world is a fault, as is the body, such must be its parts—faulty too; so in like manner must be the heaven and its celestial (contents), and everything which is conceived and produced out of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:9
verses.text: And "a corrupt tree must needs bring forth evil fruit".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:10
verses.text: The flesh of Christ, therefore, if composed of celestial elements, consists of faulty materials, sinful by reason of its sinful origin; so that it must be a part of that substance which they disdain to clothe Christ with, because of its sinfulness,—in other words, our own.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:11
verses.text: Then, as there is no difference in the point of ignominy, let them either devise for Christ some substance of a purer stamp, since they are displeased with our own, or else let them recognise this too, than which even a heavenly substance could not have been better.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:12
verses.text: We read in so many words: "The first man is of the earth, earthy; the second man is the Lord from heaven".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:13
verses.text: This passage, however, has nothing to do with any difference of substance; it only contrasts with the once "earthy" substance of the flesh of the first man, Adam, the "heavenly" substance of the spirit of the second man, Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:14
verses.text: And so entirely does the passage refer the celestial man to the spirit and not to the flesh, that those whom it compares to Him evidently become celestial—by the Spirit, of course—even in this "earthy flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:15
verses.text: Now, since Christ is heavenly even in regard to the flesh, they could not be compared to Him, who are not heavenly in reference to their flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 8:16
verses.text: If, then, they who become heavenly, as Christ also was, carry about an "earthy" substance of flesh, the conclusion which is affirmed by this fact is, that Christ Himself also was heavenly, but in an "earthy" flesh, even as they are who are put on a level with Him.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:1
verses.text: Christ's Flesh Perfectly Natural, Like Our Own.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:2
verses.text: None of the Supernatural Features Which the Heretics Ascribed to It Discoverable, on a Careful View.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:3
verses.text: We have thus far gone on the principle, that nothing which is derived from some other thing, however different it may be from that from which it is derived, is so different as not to suggest the source from which it comes.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:4
verses.text: No material substance is without the witness of its own original, however great a change into new properties it may have undergone.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:5
verses.text: There is this very body of ours, the formation of which out of the dust of the ground is a truth which has found its way into Gentile fables; it certainly testifies its own origin from the two elements of earth and water,—from the former by its flesh, from the latter by its blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:6
verses.text: Now, although there is a difference in the appearance of qualities (in other words, that which proceeds from something else is in development different), yet, after all, what is blood but red fluid? what is flesh but earth in an especial form? Consider the respective qualities,—of the muscles as clods; of the bones as stones; the mammillary glands as a kind of pebbles.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:7
verses.text: Look upon the close junctions of the nerves as propagations of roots, and the branching courses of the veins as winding rivulets, and the down (which covers us) as moss, and the hair as grass, and the very treasures of marrow within our bones as ores of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:8
verses.text: All these marks of the earthy origin were in Christ; and it is they which obscured Him as the Son of God, for He was looked on as man, for no other reason whatever than because He existed in the corporeal substance of a man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:9
verses.text: Or else, show us some celestial substance in Him purloined from the Bear, and the Pleiades, and the Hyades.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:10
verses.text: Well, then, the characteristics which we have enumerated are so many proofs that His was an earthy flesh, as ours is; but anything new or anything strange I do not discover.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:11
verses.text: Indeed it was from His words and actions only, from His teaching and miracles solely, that men, though amazed, owned Christ to be man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:12
verses.text: But if there had been in Him any new kind of flesh miraculously obtained (from the stars), it would have been certainly well known.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:13
verses.text: As the case stood, however, it was actually the ordinary condition of His terrene flesh which made all things else about Him wonderful, as when they said, "Whence hath this man this wisdom and these mighty works?" Thus spake even they who despised His outward form.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:14
verses.text: His body did not reach even to human beauty, to say nothing of heavenly glory.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:15
verses.text: Had the prophets given us no information whatever concerning His ignoble appearance, His very sufferings and the very contumely He endured bespeak it all.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:16
verses.text: The sufferings attested His human flesh, the contumely proved its abject condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:17
verses.text: Would any man have dared to touch even with his little finger, the body of Christ, if it had been of an unusual nature; or to smear His face with spitting, if it had not invited it (by its abjectness)? Why talk of a heavenly flesh, when you have no grounds to offer us for your celestial theory? Why deny it to be earthy, when you have the best of reasons for knowing it to be earthy?  He hungered under the devil's temptation; He thirsted with the woman of Samaria; He wept over Lazarus; He trembles at death (for "the flesh," as He says, "is weak"); at last, He pours out His blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 9:18
verses.text: These, I suppose, are celestial marks? But how, I ask, could He have incurred contempt and suffering in the way I have described, if there had beamed forth in that flesh of His aught of celestial excellence? From this, therefore, we have a convincing proof that in it there was nothing of heaven, because it must be capable of contempt and suffering.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:1
verses.text: Another Class of Heretics Refuted.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:2
verses.text: They Alleged that Christ's Flesh Was of a Finer Texture, Animalis, Composed of Soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:3
verses.text: I now turn to another class, who are equally wise in their own conceit.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:4
verses.text: They affirm that the flesh of Christ is composed of soul, that His soul became flesh, so that His flesh is soul; and as His flesh is of soul, so is His soul of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:5
verses.text: But here, again, I must have some reasons.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:6
verses.text: If, in order to save the soul, Christ took a soul within Himself, because it could not be saved except by Him having it within Himself, I see no reason why, in clothing Himself with flesh, He should have made that flesh one of soul, as if He could not have saved the soul in any other way than by making flesh of it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:7
verses.text: For while He saves our souls, which are not only not of flesh, but are even distinct from flesh, how much more able was He to secure salvation to that soul which He took Himself, when it was also not of flesh? Again, since they assume it as a main tenet, that Christ came forth not to deliver the flesh, but only our soul, how absurd it is, in the first place, that, meaning to save only the soul, He yet made it into just that sort of bodily substance which He had no intention of saving! And, secondly, if He had undertaken to deliver our souls by means of that which He carried, He ought, in that soul which He carried to have carried our soul, one (that is) of the same condition as ours; and whatever is the condition of our soul in its secret nature, it is certainly not one of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:8
verses.text: However, it was not our soul which He saved, if His own was of flesh; for ours is not of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:9
verses.text: Now, if He did not save our soul on the ground, that it was a soul of flesh which He saved, He is nothing to us, because He has not saved our soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:10
verses.text: Nor indeed did it need salvation, for it was not our soul really, since it was, on the supposition, a soul of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:11
verses.text: But yet it is evident that it has been saved.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:12
verses.text: Of flesh, therefore, it was not composed, and it was ours; for it was our soul that was saved, since that was in peril of damnation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 10:13
verses.text: We therefore now conclude that as in Christ the soul was not of flesh, so neither could His flesh have possibly been composed of soul.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:1
verses.text: The Opposite Extravagance Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:2
verses.text: That is Christ with a Soul Composed of Flesh—Corporeal, Though Invisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:3
verses.text: Christ's Soul, Like Ours, Distinct from Flesh, Though Clothed in It.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:4
verses.text: But we meet another argument of theirs, when we raise the question why Christ, in assuming a flesh composed of soul, should seem to have had a soul that was made of flesh? For God, they say, desired to make the soul visible to men, by enduing it with a bodily nature, although it was before invisible; of its own nature, indeed, it was incapable of seeing anything, even its own self, by reason of the obstacle of this flesh, so that it was even a matter of doubt whether it was born or not.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:5
verses.text: The soul, therefore (they further say), was made corporeal in Christ, in order that we might see it when undergoing birth, and death, and (what is more) resurrection.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:6
verses.text: But yet, how was this possible, that by means of the flesh the soul should demonstrate itself to itself or to us, when it could not possibly be ascertained that it would offer this mode of exhibiting itself by the flesh, until the thing came into existence to which it was unknown, that is to say, the flesh? It received darkness, forsooth, in order to be able to shine! Now, let us first turn our attention to this point, whether it was requisite that the soul should exhibit itself in the manner contended for; and next consider whether their previous position be that the soul is wholly invisible (inquiring further) whether this invisibility is the result of its incorporeality, or whether it actually possesses some sort of body peculiar to itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:7
verses.text: And yet, although they say that it is invisible, they determine it to be corporeal, but having somewhat that is invisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:8
verses.text: For if it has nothing invisible how can it be said to be invisible? But even its existence is an impossibility, unless it has that which is instrumental to its existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:9
verses.text: Since, however, it exists, it must needs have a something through which it exists.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:10
verses.text: If it has this something, it must be its body.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:11
verses.text: Everything which exists is a bodily existence sui generis.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:12
verses.text: Nothing lacks bodily existence but that which is non-existent.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:13
verses.text: If, then, the soul has an invisible body, He who had proposed to make it visible would certainly have done His work better if He had made that part of it which was accounted invisible, visible; because then there would have been no untruth or weakness in the case, and neither of these flaws is suitable to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:14
verses.text: (But as the case stands in the hypothesis) there is untruth, since He has set forth the soul as being a different thing from what it really is; and there is weakness, since He was unable to make it appear to be that which it is.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:15
verses.text: No one who wishes to exhibit a man covers him with a veil or a mask.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:16
verses.text: This, however, is precisely what has been done to the soul, if it has been clothed with a covering belonging to something else, by being converted into flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:17
verses.text: But even if the soul is, on their hypothesis, supposed to be incorporeal, so that the soul, whatever it is, should by some mysterious force of the reason be quite unknown, only not be a body, then in that case it were not beyond the power of God—indeed it would be more consistent with His plan—if He displayed the soul in some new sort of body, different from that which we all have in common, one of which we should have quite a different notion, (being spared the idea that) He had set His mind on making, without an adequate cause, a visible soul instead of an invisible one—a fit incentive, no doubt, for such questions as they start, by their maintenance of a human flesh for it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:18
verses.text: Christ, however, could not have appeared among men except as a man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 11:19
verses.text: Restore, therefore, to Christ, His faith; believe that He who willed to walk the earth as a man exhibited even a soul of a thoroughly human condition, not making it of flesh, but clothing it with flesh.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:1
verses.text: The True Functions of the Soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:2
verses.text: Christ Assumed It in His Perfect Human Nature, Not to Reveal and Explain It, But to Save It.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:3
verses.text: Its Resurrection with the Body Assured by Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:4
verses.text: Well, now, let it be granted that the soul is made apparent by the flesh, on the assumption that it was evidently necessary that it should be made apparent in some way or other, that is, as being incognizable to itself and to us: there is still an absurd distinction in this hypothesis, which implies that we are ourselves separate from our soul, when all that we are is soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:5
verses.text: Indeed, without the soul we are nothing; there is not even the name of a human being, only that of a carcase.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:6
verses.text: If, then, we are ignorant of the soul, it is in fact the soul that is ignorant of itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:7
verses.text: Thus the only remaining question left for us to look into is, whether the soul was in this matter so ignorant of itself that it became known in any way it could.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:8
verses.text: The soul, in my opinion, is sensual.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:9
verses.text: Nothing, therefore, pertaining to the soul is unconnected with sense, nothing pertaining to sense is unconnected with the soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:10
verses.text: And if I may use the expression for the sake of emphasis, I would say, "Animoe anima sensus est"—"Sense is the soul's very soul".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:11
verses.text: Now, since it is the soul that imparts the faculty of perception to all (that have sense), and since it is itself that perceives the very senses, not to say properties, of them all, how is it likely that it did not itself receive sense as its own natural constitution? Whence is it to know what is necessary for itself under given circumstances, from the very necessity of natural causes, if it knows not its own property, and what is necessary for it? To recognise this indeed is within the competence of every soul; it has, I mean, a practical knowledge of itself, without which knowledge of itself no soul could possibly have exercised its own functions.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:12
verses.text: I suppose, too, that it is especially suitable that man, the only rational animal, should have been furnished with such a soul as would make him the rational animal, itself being pre-eminently rational.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:13
verses.text: Now, how can that soul which makes man a rational animal be itself rational if it be itself ignorant of its rationality, being ignorant of its own very self? So far, however, is it from being ignorant, that it knows its own Author, its own Master, and its own condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:14
verses.text: Before it learns anything about God, it names the name of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:15
verses.text: Before it acquires any knowledge of His judgment, it professes to commend itself to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:16
verses.text: There is nothing one oftener hears of than that there is no hope after death; and yet what imprecations or deprecations does not the soul use according as the man dies after a well or ill spent life! These reflections are more fully pursued in a short treatise which we have written, "On the Testimony of the Soul".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:17
verses.text: Besides, if the soul was ignorant of itself from the beginning, there is nothing it could have learnt of Christ except its own quality.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:18
verses.text: It was not its own form that it learnt of Christ, but its salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:19
verses.text: For this cause did the Son of God descend and take on Him a soul, not that the soul might discover itself in Christ, but Christ in itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:20
verses.text: For its salvation is endangered, not by its being ignorant of itself, but of the word of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:21
verses.text: "The life," says He, "was manifested," not the soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:22
verses.text: And again, "I am come to save the soul".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:23
verses.text: He did not say, "to explain" it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:24
verses.text: We could not know, of course, that the soul, although an invisible essence, is born and dies, unless it were exhibited corporeally.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:25
verses.text: We certainly were ignorant that it was to rise again with the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:26
verses.text: This is the truth which it will be found was manifested by Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:27
verses.text: But even this He did not manifest in Himself in a different way than in some Lazarus, whose flesh was no more composed of soul than his soul was of flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 12:28
verses.text: What further knowledge, therefore, have we received of the structure of the soul which we were ignorant of before?  What invisible part was there belonging to it which wanted to be made visible by the flesh?.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:1
verses.text: Christ's Human Nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:2
verses.text: The Flesh and the Soul Both Fully and Unconfusedly Contained in It.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:3
verses.text: The soul became flesh that the soul might become visible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:4
verses.text: Well, then, did the flesh likewise become soul that the flesh might be manifested? If the soul is flesh, it is no longer soul, but flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:5
verses.text: If the flesh is soul, it is no longer flesh, but soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:6
verses.text: Where, then, there is flesh, and where there is soul, it has become both one and the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:7
verses.text: Now, if they are neither in particular, although they become both one and the other, it is, to say the least, very absurd, that we should understand the soul when we name the flesh, and when we indicate the soul, explain ourselves as meaning the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:8
verses.text: All things will be in danger of being taken in a sense different from their own proper sense, and, whilst taken in that different sense, of losing their proper one, if they are called by a name which differs from their natural designation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:9
verses.text: Fidelity in names secures the safe appreciation of properties.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:10
verses.text: When these properties undergo a change, they are considered to possess such qualities as their names indicate.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:11
verses.text: Baked clay, for instance, receives the name of brick.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:12
verses.text: It retains not the name which designated its former state, because it has no longer a share in that state.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:13
verses.text: Therefore, also, the soul of Christ having become flesh, cannot be anything else than that which it has become nor can it be any longer that which it once was, having become indeed something else.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:14
verses.text: And since we have just had recourse to an illustration, we will put it to further use.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:15
verses.text: Our pitcher, then, which was formed of the clay, is one body, and has one name indicative, of course, of that one body; nor can the pitcher be also called clay, because what it once was, it is no longer.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:16
verses.text: Now that which is no longer (what it was) is also not an inseparable property.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:17
verses.text: And the soul is not an inseparable property.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:18
verses.text: Since, therefore, it has become flesh, the soul is a uniform solid body; it is also a wholly incomplex being, and an indivisible substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:19
verses.text: But in Christ we find the soul and the flesh expressed in simple unfigurative terms; that is to say, the soul is called soul, and the flesh, flesh; nowhere is the soul termed flesh, or the flesh, soul; and yet they ought to have been thus (confusedly) named if such had been their condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:20
verses.text: The fact, however, is that even by Christ Himself each substance has been separately mentioned by itself, conformably of course, to the distinction which exists between the properties of both, the soul by itself, and the flesh by itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:21
verses.text: "My soul," says He, "is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death;" and "the bread that I will give is my flesh, (which I will give) for the life of the world".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:22
verses.text: Now, if the soul had been flesh, there would have only been in Christ the soul composed of flesh, or else the flesh composed of soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:23
verses.text: Since, however, He keeps the species distinct, the flesh and the soul, He shows them to be two.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:24
verses.text: If two, then they are no longer one; if not one, then the soul is not composed of flesh, nor the flesh of soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:25
verses.text: For the soul-flesh, or the flesh-soul, is but one; unless indeed He even had some other soul apart from that which was flesh, and bare about another flesh besides that which was soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 13:26
verses.text: But since He had but one flesh and one soul,—that "soul which was sorrowful, even unto death," and that flesh which was the "bread given for the life of the world,"—the number is unimpaired of two substances distinct in kind, thus excluding the unique species of the flesh-comprised soul.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:1
verses.text: Christ Took Not on Him an Angelic Nature, But the Human.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:2
verses.text: It Was Men, Not Angels, Whom He Came to Save.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:3
verses.text: But Christ, they say, bare (the nature of) an angel.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:4
verses.text: For what reason? The same which induced Him to become man? Christ, then, was actuated by the motive which led Him to take human nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:5
verses.text: Man's salvation was the motive, the restoration of that which had perished.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:6
verses.text: Man had perished; his recovery had become necessary.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:7
verses.text: No such cause, however, existed for Christ's taking on Him the nature of angels.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:8
