verses.text: For although there is assigned to angels also perdition in "the fire prepared for the devil and his angels," yet a restoration is never promised to them.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:9
verses.text: No charge about the salvation of angels did Christ ever receive from the Father; and that which the Father neither promised nor commanded, Christ could not have undertaken.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:10
verses.text: For what object, therefore, did He bear the angelic nature, if it were not (that He might have it) as a powerful helper wherewithal to execute the salvation of man?  The Son of God, in sooth, was not competent alone to deliver man, whom a solitary and single serpent had overthrown!  There is, then, no longer but one God, but one Saviour, if there be two to contrive salvation, and one of them in need of the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:11
verses.text: But was it His object indeed to deliver man by an angel? Why, then, come down to do that which He was about to expedite with an angel's help? If by an angel's aid, why come Himself also? If He meant to do all by Himself, why have an angel too? He has been, it is true, called "the Angel of great counsel," that is, a messenger, by a term expressive of official function, not of nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:12
verses.text: For He had to announce to the world the mighty purpose of the Father, even that which ordained the restoration of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:13
verses.text: But He is not on this account to be regarded as an angel, as a Gabriel or a Michael.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:14
verses.text: For the Lord of the Vineyard sends even His Son to the labourers to require fruit, as well as His servants.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:15
verses.text: Yet the Son will not therefore be counted as one of the servants because He undertook the office of a servant.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:16
verses.text: I may, then, more easily say, if such an expression is to be hazarded, that the Son is actually an angel, that is, a messenger, from the Father, than that there is an angel in the Son.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:17
verses.text: Forasmuch, however, as it has been declared concerning the Son Himself, "Thou hast made Him a little lower than the angels" how will it appear that He put on the nature of angels if He was made lower than the angels, having become man, with flesh and soul as the Son of man? As "the Spirit of God," however, and "the Power of the Highest," can He be regarded as lower than the angels,—He who is verily God, and the Son of God? Well, but as bearing human nature, He is so far made inferior to the angels; but as bearing angelic nature, He to the same degree loses that inferiority.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:18
verses.text: This opinion will be very suitable for Ebion, who holds Jesus to be a mere man, and nothing more than a descendant of David, and not also the Son of God; although He is, to be sure, in one respect more glorious than the prophets, inasmuch as he declares that there was an angel in Him, just as there was in Zechariah.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:19
verses.text: Only it was never said by Christ, "And the angel, which spake within me, said unto me".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:20
verses.text: Neither, indeed, was ever used by Christ that familiar phrase of all the prophets, "Thus saith the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:21
verses.text: For He was Himself the Lord, who openly spake by His own authority, prefacing His words with the formula, "Verily, verily, I say unto you".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 14:22
verses.text: What need is there of further argument? Hear what Isaiah says in emphatic words, "It was no angel, nor deputy, but the Lord Himself who saved them".

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:1
verses.text: The Valentinian Figment of Christ's Flesh Being of a Spiritual Nature, Examined and Refuted Out of Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:2
verses.text: Valentinus, indeed, on the strength of his heretical system, might consistently devise a spiritual flesh for Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:3
verses.text: Any one who refused to believe that that flesh was human might pretend it to be anything he liked, forasmuch as (and this remark is applicable to all heretics), if it was not human, and was not born of man, I do not see of what substance Christ Himself spoke when He called Himself man and the Son of man, saying: "But now ye seek to kill me, a man that hath told you the truth;" and "The Son of man is Lord of the Sabbath-day".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:4
verses.text: For it is of Him that Isaiah writes: "A man of suffering, and acquainted with the bearing of weakness;" and Jeremiah: "He is a man, and who hath known Him?" and Daniel: "Upon the clouds (He came) as the Son of man".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:5
verses.text: The Apostle Paul likewise says: "The man Christ Jesus is the one Mediator between God and man".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:6
verses.text: Also Peter, in the Acts of the Apostles, speaks of Him as verily human (when he says), "Jesus Christ was a man approved of God among you".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:7
verses.text: These passages alone ought to suffice as a prescriptive testimony in proof that Christ had human flesh derived from man, and not spiritual, and that His flesh was not composed of soul, nor of stellar substance, and that it was not an imaginary flesh; (and no doubt they would be sufficient) if heretics could only divest themselves of all their contentious warmth and artifice.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:8
verses.text: For, as I have read in some writer of Valentinus' wretched faction, they refuse at the outset to believe that a human and earthly substance was created for Christ, lest the Lord should be regarded as inferior to the angels, who are not formed of earthly flesh; whence, too, it would be necessary that, if His flesh were like ours, it should be similarly born, not of the Spirit, nor of God, but of the will of man.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:9
verses.text: Why, moreover, should it be born, not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible? Why, again, since His flesh has both risen and returned to heaven, is not ours, being like His, also taken up at once? Or else, why does not His flesh, since it is like ours, return in like manner to the ground, and suffer dissolution? Such objections even the heathen used constantly to bandy about.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:10
verses.text: Was the Son of God reduced to such a depth of degradation? Again, if He rose again as a precedent for our hope, how is it that nothing like it has been thought desirable (to happen) to ourselves? Such views are not improper for heathens and they are fit and natural for the heretics too.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:11
verses.text: For, indeed, what difference is there between them, except it be that the heathen, in not believing, do believe; while the heretics, in believing, do not believe? Then, again, they read: "Thou madest Him a little less than angels;" and they deny the lower nature of that Christ who declares Himself to be, "not a man, but a worm;" who also had "no form nor comeliness, but His form was ignoble, despised more than all men, a man in suffering, and acquainted with the bearing of weakness".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:12
verses.text: Here they discover a human being mingled with a divine one and so they deny the manhood.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:13
verses.text: They believe that He died, and maintain that a being which has died was born of an incorruptible substance; as if, forsooth, corruptibility were something else than death! But our flesh, too, ought immediately to have risen again.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:14
verses.text: Wait a while.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 15:15
verses.text: Christ has not yet subdued His enemies, so as to be able to triumph over them in company with His friends.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:1
verses.text: Christ's Flesh in Nature, the Same as Ours, Only Sinless.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:2
verses.text: The Difference Between Carnem Peccati and Peccatum Carnis: It is the Latter Which Christ Abolished.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:3
verses.text: The Flesh of the First Adam, No Less Than that of the Second Adam, Not Received from Human Seed, Although as Entirely Human as Our Own, Which is Derived from It.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:4
verses.text: The famous Alexander, too, instigated by his love of disputation in the true fashion of heretical temper, has made himself conspicuous against us; he will have us say that Christ put on flesh of an earthly origin, in order that He might in His own person abolish sinful flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:5
verses.text: Now, even if we did assert this as our opinion, we should be able to defend it in such a way as completely to avoid the extravagant folly which he ascribes to us in making us suppose that the very flesh of Christ was in Himself abolished as being sinful; because we mention our belief (in public), that it is sitting at the right hand of the Father in heaven; and we further declare that it will come again from thence in all the pomp of the Father's glory: it is therefore just as impossible for us to say that it is abolished, as it is for us to maintain that it is sinful, and so made void, since in it there has been no fault.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:6
verses.text: We maintain, moreover, that what has been abolished in Christ is not carnem peccati, "sinful flesh," but peccatum carnis, "sin in the flesh,"—not the material thing, but its condition; not the substance, but its flaw; and (this we aver) on the authority of the apostle, who says, "He abolished sin in the flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:7
verses.text: Now in another sentence he says that Christ was "in the likeness of sinful flesh," not, however, as if He had taken on Him "the likeness of the flesh," in the sense of a semblance of body instead of its reality; but he means us to understand likeness to the flesh which sinned, because the flesh of Christ, which committed no sin itself, resembled that which had sinned,—resembled it in its nature, but not in the corruption it received from Adam; whence we also affirm that there was in Christ the same flesh as that whose nature in man is sinful.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:8
verses.text: In the flesh, therefore, we say that sin has been abolished, because in Christ that same flesh is maintained without sin, which in man was not maintained without sin.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:9
verses.text: Now, it would not contribute to the purpose of Christ's abolishing sin in the flesh, if He did not abolish it in that flesh in which was the nature of sin, nor (would it conduce) to His glory.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:10
verses.text: For surely it would have been no strange thing if He had removed the stain of sin in some better flesh, and one which should possess a different, even a sinless, nature! Then, you say, if He took our flesh, Christ's was a sinful one.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:11
verses.text: Do not, however, fetter with mystery a sense which is quite intelligible.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:12
verses.text: For in putting on our flesh, He made it His own; in making it His own, He made it sinless.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:13
verses.text: A word of caution, however, must be addressed to all who refuse to believe that our flesh was in Christ on the ground that it came not of the seed of a human father, let them remember that Adam himself received this flesh of ours without the seed of a human father.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 16:14
verses.text: As earth was converted into this flesh of ours without the seed of a human father, so also was it quite possible for the Son of God to take to Himself the substance of the selfsame flesh, without a human father's agency.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:1
verses.text: The Similarity of Circumstances Between the First and the Second Adam, as to the Derivation of Their Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:2
verses.text: An Analogy Also Pleasantly Traced Between Eve and the Virgin Mary.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:3
verses.text: But, leaving Alexander with his syllogisms, which he so perversely applies in his discussions, as well as with the hymns of Valentinus, which, with consummate assurance, he interpolates as the production of some respectable author, let us confine our inquiry to a single point—Whether Christ received flesh from the virgin?—that we may thus arrive at a certain proof that His flesh was human, if He derived its substance from His mother's womb, although we are at once furnished with clear evidences of the human character of His flesh, from its name and description as that of a man, and from the nature of its constitution, and from the system of its sensations, and from its suffering of death.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:4
verses.text: Now, it will first be necessary to show what previous reason there was for the Son of God's being born of a virgin.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:5
verses.text: He who was going to consecrate a new order of birth, must Himself be born after a novel fashion, concerning which Isaiah foretold how that the Lord Himself would give the sign.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:6
verses.text: What, then, is the sign? "Behold a virgin shall conceive and bear a son".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:7
verses.text: Accordingly, a virgin did conceive and bear "Emmanuel, God with us".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:8
verses.text: This is the new nativity; a man is born in God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:9
verses.text: And in this man God was born, taking the flesh of an ancient race, without the help, however, of the ancient seed, in order that He might reform it with a new seed, that is, in a spiritual manner, and cleanse it by the re-moval of all its ancient stains.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:10
verses.text: But the whole of this new birth was prefigured, as was the case in all other instances, in ancient type, the Lord being born as man by a dispensation in which a virgin was the medium.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:11
verses.text: The earth was still in a virgin state, reduced as yet by no human labour, with no seed as yet cast into its furrows, when, as we are told, God made man out of it into a living soul.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:12
verses.text: As, then, the first Adam is thus introduced to us, it is a just inference that the second Adam likewise, as the apostle has told us, was formed by God into a quickening spirit out of the ground,—in other words, out of a flesh which was unstained as yet by any human generation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:13
verses.text: But that I may lose no opportunity of supporting my argument from the name of Adam, why is Christ called Adam by the apostle, unless it be that, as man, He was of that earthly origin? And even reason here maintains the same conclusion, because it was by just the contrary operation that God recovered His own image and likeness, of which He had been robbed by the devil.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:14
verses.text: For it was while Eve was yet a virgin, that the ensnaring word had crept into her ear which was to build the edifice of death.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:15
verses.text: Into a virgin's soul, in like manner, must be introduced that Word of God which was to raise the fabric of life; so that what had been reduced to ruin by this sex, might by the selfsame sex be recovered to salvation.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:16
verses.text: As Eve had believed the serpent, so Mary believed the angel.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:17
verses.text: The delinquency which the one occasioned by believing, the other by believing effaced.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:18
verses.text: But (it will be said) Eve did not at the devil's word conceive in her womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:19
verses.text: Well, she at all events conceived; for the devil's word afterwards became as seed to her that she should conceive as an outcast, and bring forth in sorrow.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:20
verses.text: Indeed she gave birth to a fratricidal devil; whilst Mary, on the contrary, bare one who was one day to secure salvation to Israel, His own brother after the flesh, and the murderer of Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:21
verses.text: God therefore sent down into the virgin's womb His Word, as the good Brother, who should blot out the memory of the evil brother.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 17:22
verses.text: Hence it was necessary that Christ should come forth for the salvation of man, in that condition of flesh into which man had entered ever since his condemnation.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:1
verses.text: The Mystery of the Assumption of Our Perfect Human Nature by the Second Person of the Blessed Trinity.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:2
verses.text: He is Here Called, as Often Elsewhere, the Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:3
verses.text: Now, that we may give a simpler answer, it was not fit that the Son of God should be born of a human father's seed, lest, if He were wholly the Son of a man, He should fail to be also the Son of God, and have nothing more than "a Solomon" or "a Jonas,"—as Ebion thought we ought to believe concerning Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:4
verses.text: In order, therefore, that He who was already the Son of God—of God the Father's seed, that is to say, the Spirit—might also be the Son of man, He only wanted to assume flesh, of the flesh of man without the seed of a man; for the seed of a man was unnecessary for One who had the seed of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:5
verses.text: As, then, before His birth of the virgin, He was able to have God for His Father without a human mother, so likewise, after He was born of the virgin, He was able to have a woman for His mother without a human father.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:6
verses.text: He is thus man with God, in short, since He is man's flesh with God's Spirit—flesh (I say) without seed from man, Spirit with seed from God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:7
verses.text: For as much, then, as the dispensation of God's purpose concerning His Son required that He should be born of a virgin, why should He not have received of the virgin the body which He bore from the virgin? Because, (forsooth) it is something else which He took from God, for "the Word" say they, "was made flesh".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:8
verses.text: Now this very statement plainly shows what it was that was made flesh; nor can it possibly be that anything else than the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:9
verses.text: Now, whether it was of the flesh that the Word was made flesh, or whether it was so made of the (divine) seed itself, the Scripture must tell us.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:10
verses.text: As, however, the Scripture is silent about everything except what it was that was made (flesh), and says nothing of that from which it was so made, it must be held to suggest that from something else, and not from itself, was the Word made flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:11
verses.text: And if not from itself, but from something else, from what can we more suitably suppose that the Word became flesh than from that flesh in which it submitted to the dispensation? And (we have a proof of the same conclusion in the fact) that the Lord Himself sententiously and distinctly pronounced, "that which is born of the flesh is flesh," even because it is born of the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:12
verses.text: But if He here spoke of a human being simply, and not of Himself, (as you maintain) then you must deny absolutely that Christ is man, and must maintain that human nature was not suitable to Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:13
verses.text: And then He adds, "That which is born of the Spirit is spirit," because God is a Spirit, and He was born of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:14
verses.text: Now this description is certainly even more applicable to Him than it is to those who believe in Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:15
verses.text: But if this passage indeed apply to Him, then why does not the preceding one also? For you cannot divide their relation, and adapt this to Him, and the previous clause to all other men, especially as you do not deny that Christ possesses the two substances, both of the flesh and of the Spirit.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:16
verses.text: Besides, as He was in possession both of flesh and of Spirit, He cannot possibly, when speaking of the condition of the two substances which He Himself bears, be supposed to have determined that the Spirit indeed was His own, but that the flesh was not His own.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 18:17
verses.text: Forasmuch, therefore, as He is of the Spirit He is God the Spirit, and is born of God; just as He is also born of the flesh of man, being generated in the flesh as man.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:1
verses.text: Christ, as to His Divine Nature, as the Word of God, Became Flesh, Not by Carnal Conception, Nor by the Will of the Flesh and of Man, But by the Will of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:2
verses.text: Christ's Divine Nature, of Its Own Accord, Descended into the Virgin's Womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:3
verses.text: What, then, is the meaning of this passage, "Born not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God?" I shall make more use of this passage after I have confuted those who have tampered with it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:4
verses.text: They maintain that it was written thus (in the plural) "Who were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God," as if designating those who were before mentioned as "believing in His name," in order to point out the existence of that mysterious seed of the elect and spiritual which they appropriate to themselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:5
verses.text: But how can this be, when all who believe in the name of the Lord are, by reason of the common principle of the human race, born of blood, and of the will of the flesh, and of man, as indeed is Valentinus himself? The expression is in the singular number, as referring to the Lord, "He was born of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:6
verses.text: And very properly, because Christ is the Word of God, and with the Word the Spirit of God, and by the Spirit the Power of God, and whatsoever else appertains to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:7
verses.text: As flesh, however, He is not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of man, because it was by the will of God that the Word was made flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:8
verses.text: To the flesh, indeed, and not to the Word, accrues the denial of the nativity which is natural to us all as men, because it was as flesh that He had thus to be born, and not as the Word.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:9
verses.text: Now, whilst the passage actually denies that He was born of the will of the flesh, how is it that it did not also deny (that He was born) of the substance of the flesh?  For it did not disavow the substance of the flesh when it denied His being "born of blood" but only the matter of the seed, which, as all know, is the warm blood as convected by ebullition into the coagulum of the woman's blood.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:10
verses.text: In the cheese, it is from the coagulation that the milky substance acquires that consistency, which is condensed by infusing the rennet.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:11
verses.text: We thus understand that what is denied is the Lord's birth after sexual intercourse (as is suggested by the phrase, "the will of man and of the flesh"), not His nativity from a woman's womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:12
verses.text: Why, too, is it insisted on with such an accumulation of emphasis that He was not born of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor (of the will) of man, if it were not that His flesh was such that no man could have any doubt on the point of its being born from sexual intercourse?  Again, although denying His birth from such cohabitation, the passage did not deny that He was born of real flesh; it rather affirmed this, by the very fact that it did not deny His birth in the flesh in the same way that it denied His birth from sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:13
verses.text: Pray, tell me, why the Spirit of God descended into a woman's womb at all, if He did not do so for the purpose of partaking of flesh from the womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:14
verses.text: For He could have become spiritual flesh without such a process,—much more simply, indeed, without the womb than in it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:15
verses.text: He had no reason for enclosing Himself within one, if He was to bear forth nothing from it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:16
verses.text: Not without reason, however, did He descend into a womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 19:17
verses.text: Therefore He received (flesh) therefrom; else, if He received nothing therefrom, His descent into it would have been without a reason, especially if He meant to become flesh of that sort which was not derived from a womb, that is to say, a spiritual one.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:1
verses.text: Christ Born of a Virgin, of Her Substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:2
verses.text: The Physiological Facts of His Real and Exact Birth of a Human Mother, as Suggested by Certain Passages of Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:3
verses.text: But to what shifts you resort, in your attempt to rob the syllable ex (of) of its proper force as a preposition, and to substitute another for it in a sense not found throughout the Holy Scriptures!  You say that He was born through a virgin, not of a virgin, and in a womb, not of a womb, because the angel in the dream said to Joseph, "That which is born in her" (not of her) "is of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:4
verses.text: But the fact is, if he had meant "of her," he must have said "in her;" for that which was of her, was also in her.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:5
verses.text: The angel's expression, therefore, "in her," has precisely the same meaning as the phrase "of her".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:6
verses.text: It is, however, a fortunate circumstance that Matthew also, when tracing down the Lord's descent from Abraham to Mary, says, "Jacob begat Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom was born Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:7
verses.text: But Paul, too, silences these critics when he says, "God sent forth His Son, made of a woman".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:8
verses.text: Does he mean through a woman, or in a woman? Nay more, for the sake of greater emphasis, he uses the word "made" rather than born, although the use of the latter expression would have been simpler.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:9
verses.text: But by saying "made," he not only confirmed the statement, "The Word was made flesh," but he also asserted the reality of the flesh which was made of a virgin.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:10
verses.text: We shall have also the support of the Psalms on this point, not the "Psalms" indeed of Valentinus the apostate, and heretic, and Platonist, but the Psalms of David, the most illustrious saint and well-known prophet.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:11
verses.text: He sings to us of Christ, and through his voice Christ indeed also sang concerning Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:12
verses.text: Hear, then, Christ the Lord speaking to God the Father: "Thou art He that didst draw me out of my mother's womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:13
verses.text: Here is the first point.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:14
verses.text: "Thou art my hope from my mother's breasts; upon Thee have I been cast from the womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:15
verses.text: Here is another point.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:16
verses.text: "Thou art my God from my mother's belly".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:17
verses.text: Here is a third point.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:18
verses.text: Now let us carefully attend to the sense of these passages.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:19
verses.text: "Thou didst draw me," He says, "out of the womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:20
verses.text: Now what is it which is drawn, if it be not that which adheres, that which is firmly fastened to anything from which it is drawn in order to be sundered? If He clove not to the womb, how could He have been drawn from it? If He who clove thereto was drawn from it, how could He have adhered to it, if it were not that, all the while He was in the womb, He was tied to it, as to His origin, by the umbilical cord, which communicated growth to Him from the matrix? Even when one strange matter amalgamates with another, it becomes so entirely incorporated with that with which it amalgamates, that when it is drawn off from it, it carries with it some part of the body from which it is torn, as if in consequence of the severance of the union and growth which the constituent pieces had communicated to each other.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:21
verses.text: But what were His "mother's breasts" which He mentions? No doubt they were those which He sucked.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:22
verses.text: Midwives, and doctors, and naturalists, can tell us, from the nature of women's breasts, whether they usually flow at any other time than when the womb is affected with pregnancy, when the veins convey therefrom the blood of the lower parts to the mamilla, and in the act of transference convert the secretion into the nutritious substance of milk.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:23
verses.text: Whence it comes to pass that during the period of lactation the monthly issues are suspended.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:24
verses.text: But if the Word was made flesh of Himself without any communication with a womb, no mother's womb operating upon Him with its usual function and support, how could the lacteal fountain have been conveyed (from the womb) to the breasts, since (the womb) can only effect the change by actual possession of the proper substance? But it could not possibly have had blood for transformation into milk, unless it possessed the causes of blood also, that is to say, the severance (by birth) of its own flesh from the mother's womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:25
verses.text: Now it is easy to see what was the novelty of Christ's being born of a virgin.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 20:26
verses.text: It was simply this, that (He was born) of a virgin in the real manner which we have indicated, in order that our regeneration might have virginal purity,—spiritually cleansed from all pollutions through Christ, who was Himself a virgin, even in the flesh, in that He was born of a virgin's flesh.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:1
verses.text: The Word of God Did Not Become Flesh Except in the Virgin's Womb and of Her Substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:2
verses.text: Through His Mother He is Descended from Her Great Ancestor David.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:3
verses.text: He is Described Both in the Old and in the New Testament as "The Fruit of David's Loins".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:4
verses.text: Whereas, then, they contend that the novelty (of Christ's birth) consisted in this, that as the Word of God became flesh without the seed of a human father, so there should be no flesh of the virgin mother (assisting in the transaction), why should not the novelty rather be confined to this, that His flesh, although not born of seed, should yet have proceeded from flesh? I should like to go more closely into this discussion.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:5
verses.text: "Behold," says he, "a virgin shall conceive in the womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:6
verses.text: Conceive what? I ask.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:7
verses.text: The Word of God, of course, and not the seed of man, and in order, certainly, to bring forth a son.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:8
verses.text: "For," says he, "she shall bring forth a son".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:9
verses.text: Therefore, as the act of conception was her own, so also what she brought forth was her own, also, although the cause of conception was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:10
verses.text: If, on the other hand, the Word became flesh of Himself, then He both conceived and brought forth Himself, and the prophecy is stultified.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:11
verses.text: For in that case a virgin did not conceive, and did not bring forth; since whatever she brought forth from the conception of the Word, is not her own flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:12
verses.text: But is this the only statement of prophecy which will be frustrated? Will not the angel's announcement also be subverted, that the virgin should "conceive in her womb and bring forth a son?" And will not in fact every scripture which declares that Christ had a mother? For how could she have been His mother, unless He had been in her womb? But then He received nothing from her womb which could make her a mother in whose womb He had been.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:13
verses.text: Such a name as this a strange flesh ought not to assume.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:14
verses.text: No flesh can speak of a mother's womb but that which is itself the offspring of that womb; nor can any be the offspring of the said womb if it owe its birth solely to itself.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:15
verses.text: Therefore even Elisabeth must be silent although she is carrying in her womb the prophetic babe, which was already conscious of his Lord, and is, moreover, filled with the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:16
verses.text: For without reason does she say, "and whence is this to me that the mother of my Lord should come to me?" If it was not as her son, but only as a stranger that Mary carried Jesus in her womb, how is it she says, "Blessed is the fruit of thy womb"? What is this fruit of the womb, which received not its germ from the womb, which had not its root in the womb, which belongs not to her whose is the womb, and which is no doubt the real fruit of the womb—even Christ? Now, since He is the blossom of the stem which sprouts from the root of Jesse; since, moreover, the root of Jesse is the family of David, and the stem of the root is Mary descended from David, and the blossom of the stem is Mary's son, who is called Jesus Christ, will not He also be the fruit?  For the blossom is the fruit, because through the blossom and from the blossom every product advances from its rudimental condition to perfect fruit.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:17
verses.text: What then? They, deny to the fruit its blossom, and to the blossom its stem, and to the stem its root; so that the root fails to secure for itself, by means of the stem, that special product which comes from the stem, even the blossom and the fruit; for every step indeed in a genealogy is traced from the latest up to the first, so that it is now a well-known fact that the flesh of Christ is inseparable, not merely from Mary, but also from David through Mary, and from Jesse through David.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:18
verses.text: "This fruit," therefore, "of David's loins," that is to say, of his posterity in the flesh, God swears to him that "He will raise up to sit upon his throne".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 21:19
verses.text: If "of David's loins," how much rather is He of Mary's loins, by virtue of whom He is in "the loins of David?".

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:1
verses.text: Holy Scripture in the New Testament, Even in Its Very First Verse, Testifies to Christ's True Flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:2
verses.text: In Virtue of Which He is Incorporated in the Human Stock of David, and Abraham, and Adam.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:3
verses.text: They may, then, obliterate the testimony of the devils which proclaimed Jesus the son of David; but whatever unworthiness there be in this testimony, that of the apostles they will never be able to efface.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:4
verses.text: There is, first of all, Matthew, that most faithful chronicler of the Gospel, because the companion of the Lord; for no other reason in the world than to show us clearly the fleshly original of Christ, he thus begins his Gospel: "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:5
verses.text: With a nature issuing from such fountal sources, and an order gradually descending to the birth of Christ, what else have we here described than the very flesh of Abraham and of David conveying itself down, step after step, to the very virgin, and at last introducing Christ,—nay, producing Christ Himself of the virgin? Then, again, there is Paul, who was at once both a disciple, and a master, and a witness of the selfsame Gospel; as an apostle of the same Christ, also, he affirms that Christ "was made of the seed of David, according to the flesh,"—which, therefore, was His own likewise.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:6
verses.text: Christ's flesh, then, is of David's seed.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:7
verses.text: Since He is of the seed of David in consequence of Mary's flesh, He is therefore of Mary's flesh because of the seed of David.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:8
verses.text: In what way so ever you torture the statement, He is either of the flesh of Mary because of the seed of David, or He is of the seed of David because of the flesh of Mary.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:9
verses.text: The whole discussion is terminated by the same apostle, when he declares Christ to be "the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:10
verses.text: And if of Abraham, how much more, to be sure, of David, as a more recent progenitor! For, unfolding the promised blessing upon all nations in the person of Abraham, "And in thy seed shall all nations of the earth be blessed," he adds, "He saith not, And to seeds, as of many; but as of one, And to thy seed, which is Christ".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:11
verses.text: When we read and believe these things, what sort of flesh ought we, and can we, acknowledge in Christ? Surely none other than Abraham's, since Christ is "the seed of Abraham;" none other than Jesse's, since Christ is the blossom of "the stem of Jesse;" none other than David's, since Christ is "the fruit of David's loins;" none other than Mary's, since Christ came from Mary's womb; and, higher still, none other than Adam's, since Christ is "the second Adam".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 22:12
verses.text: The consequence, therefore, is that they must either maintain, that those (ancestors) had a spiritual flesh, that so there might be derived to Christ the same condition of substance, or else allow that the flesh of Christ was not a spiritual one, since it is not traced from the origin of a spiritual stock.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:1
verses.text: Simeon's "Sign that Should Be Contradicted," Applied to the Heretical Gainsaying of the True Birth of Christ.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:2
verses.text: One of the Heretics' Paradoxes Turned in Support of Catholic Truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:3
verses.text: We acknowledge, however, that the prophetic declaration of Simeon is fulfilled, which he spoke over the recently-born Saviour: "Behold, this child is set for the fall and rising again of many in Israel, and for a sign that shall be spoken against".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:4
verses.text: The sign (here meant) is that of the birth of Christ, according to Isaiah: "Therefore the Lord Himself shall give you a sign: behold, a virgin shall conceive and bear a son".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:5
verses.text: We discover, then, what the sign is which is to be spoken against—the conception and the parturition of the Virgin Mary, concerning which these sophists say: "She a virgin and yet not a virgin bare, and yet did not bear;" just as if such language, if indeed it must be uttered, would not be more suitable even for ourselves to use! For "she bare," because she produced offspring of her own flesh and "yet she did not bear," since she produced Him not from a husband's seed; she was "a virgin," so far as (abstinence) from a husband went, and "yet not a virgin," as regards her bearing a child.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:6
verses.text: There is not, however, that parity of reasoning which the heretics affect: in other words it does not follow that for the reason "she did not bear," she who was "not a virgin" was "yet a virgin," even because she became a mother without any fruit of her own womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:7
verses.text: But with us there is no equivocation, nothing twisted into a double sense.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:8
verses.text: Light is light; and darkness, darkness; yea is yea; and nay, nay; "whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:9
verses.text: She who bare (really) bare; and although she was a virgin when she conceived, she was a wife when she brought forth her son.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:10
verses.text: Now, as a wife, she was under the very law of "opening the womb," wherein it was quite immaterial whether the birth of the male was by virtue of a husband's co-operation or not; it was the same sex that opened her womb.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:11
verses.text: Indeed, hers is the womb on account of which it is written of others also: "Every male that openeth the womb shall be called holy to the Lord".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:12
verses.text: For who is really holy but the Son of God? Who properly opened the womb but He who opened a closed one? But it is marriage which opens the womb in all cases.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:13
verses.text: The virgin's womb, therefore, was especially opened, because it was especially closed.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:14
verses.text: Indeed she ought rather to be called not a virgin than a virgin, becoming a mother at a leap, as it were, before she was a wife.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:15
verses.text: And what must be said more on this point? Since it was in this sense that the apostle declared that the Son of God was born not of a virgin, but "of a woman," he in that statement recognised the condition of the "opened womb" which ensues in marriage.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:16
verses.text: We read in Ezekiel of "a heifer which brought forth, and still did not bring forth".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 23:17
verses.text: Now, see whether it was not in view of your own future contentions about the womb of Mary, that even then the Holy Ghost set His mark upon you in this passage; otherwise He would not, contrary to His usual simplicity of style (in this prophet), have uttered a sentence of such doubtful import, especially when Isaiah says, "She shall conceive and bear a son".

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:1
verses.text: Divine Strictures on Various Heretics Descried in Various Passages of Prophetical Scripture.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:2
verses.text: Those Who Assail the True Doctrine of the One Lord Jesus Christ, Both God and Man, Thus Condemned.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:3
verses.text: For when Isaiah hurls denunciation against our very heretics, especially in his "Woe to them that call evil good, and put darkness for light," he of course sets his mark upon those amongst you who preserve not in the words they employ the light of their true significance, (by taking care) that the soul should mean only that which is so called, and the flesh simply that which is confest to our view, and God none other than the One who is preached.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:4
verses.text: Having thus Marcion in his prophetic view, he says, "I am God, and there is none else; there is no God beside me".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:5
verses.text: And when in another passage he says, in like manner, "Before me there was no God," he strikes at those inexplicable genealogies of the Valentinian aeons.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:6
verses.text: Again, there is an answer to Ebion in the Scripture: "Born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:7
verses.text: In like manner, in the passage, "If even an angel of heaven preach unto you any other gospel than that which we have preached unto you, let him be anathema," he calls attention to the artful influence of Philumene, the virgin friend of Apelles.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:8
verses.text: Surely he is antichrist who denies that Christ has come in the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:9
verses.text: By declaring that His flesh is simply and absolutely true, and taken in the plain sense of its own nature, the Scripture aims a blow at all who make distinctions in it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:10
verses.text: In the same way, also, when it defines the very Christ to be but one, it shakes the fancies of those who exhibit a multiform Christ, who make Christ to be one being and Jesus another,—representing one as escaping out of the midst of the crowds, and the other as detained by them; one as appearing on a solitary mountain to three companions, clothed with glory in a cloud, the other as an ordinary man holding intercourse with all, one as magnanimous, but the other as timid; lastly, one as suffering death, the other as risen again, by means of which event they maintain a resurrection of their own also, only in another flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:11
verses.text: Happily, however, He who suffered "will come again from heaven," and by all shall He be seen, who rose again from the dead.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 24:12
verses.text: They too who crucified Him shall see and acknowledge Him; that is to say, His very flesh, against which they spent their fury, and without which it would be impossible for Himself either to exist or to be seen; so that they must blush with shame who affirm that His flesh sits in heaven void of sensation, like a sheath only, Christ being withdrawn from it; as well as those who (maintain) that His flesh and soul are just the same thing, or else that His soul is all that exists, but that His flesh no longer lives.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:1
verses.text: Conclusion.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:2
verses.text: This Treatise Forms a Preface to the Other Work, "On the Resurrection of the Flesh," Proving the Reality of the Flesh Which Was Truly Born, and Died, and Rose Again.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:3
verses.text: But let this suffice on our present subject; for I think that by this time proof enough has been adduced of the flesh in Christ having both been born of the virgin, and being human in its nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:4
verses.text: And this discussion alone might have been sufficient, without encountering the isolated opinions which have been raised from different quarters.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:5
verses.text: We have, however, challenged these opinions to the test, both of the arguments which sustain them, and of the Scriptures which are appealed to, and this we have done ex abundanti; so that we have, by showing what the flesh of Christ was, and whence it was derived, also predetermined the question, against all objectors, of what that flesh was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 25:6
verses.text: The resurrection, however, of our own flesh will have to be maintained in another little treatise, and so bring to a close this present one, which serves as a general preface, and which will pave the way for the approaching subject now that it is plain what kind of body that was which rose again in Christ.

chapters.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:1
verses.text: -  The learned John Scott, in his invaluable work The Christian Life, identifies the glory shed upon the Saviour at his baptism, with that mentioned by Ezekiel (Cap.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:2
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:3
verses.text: ) and adds: "In this same glorious splendor was Christ arrayed first at his Baptism and afterward at his Transfiguration.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:4
verses.text: …By the Holy Ghost's descending like a Dove, it is not necessary we should understand his descending in the shape or form of a Dove, but that in some glorious form, or appearance, he descended in the same manner as a Dove descends.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:5
verses.text: …Came down from above just as a dove with his wings spread forth is observed to do, and lighted upon our Saviour's head".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:6
verses.text: I quote this as the opinion of one of the most learned and orthodox of divines, but not as my own, for I cannot reconcile it, as he strives to do, with St.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:7
verses.text: Luke iii.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:8
verses.text: Compare Justin Martyr, vol.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:9
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:10
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:11
verses.text: , and note , this series.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:12
verses.text: Grotius observes, says Dr.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:13
verses.text: Scott, that in the apocryphal Gospel of the Nazarenes, it is said that at the Baptism of our Lord "a great light shone round about the place".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:14
verses.text: -  It is not possible that the author of this chapter had ever conceived of the Blessed Virgin otherwise than as "Blessed among women," indeed, but enjoying no especial prerogative as the mother of our Lord.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:15
verses.text: He speaks of "denying her" and "putting her away" after He began His Ministry, as He requires His ministers to do, after His example.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:16
verses.text: How extraordinary this language—"the repudiation of carnal relationship".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:17
verses.text: According to our author, never charged with heresy on this point, the high rewards of the holy Mary, in the world to come will be those due to her faith, not to the blessing of "her breasts and of her womb".

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:18
verses.text: Christ designates those as "more blessed," who hear His word and keep it.

verses.name: Tertullian: On the Flesh of Christ 26:19
verses.text: This the Blessed Virgin did pre-eminently, and herein was her own greater blessedness; that is, (our author shews) her crown of glory depends chiefly, like that of other saints, on her faith and works, not on her mere Maternity.
